title: How does it feel to be a hundred years old? - Quora

response.answer_text: My great aunt (currently living in my home) was born in 1918, so she is 98 this year. I think she’s very lonely. She was not a pleasant person in her youth, so she doesn’t have any friends now… (until I realize that well, she’s almost 100, so...) But still: she was not a pleasant person when she was younger, and in hindsight I think she has borderline or maybe paranoid personality disorder. Until about 5 years ago she was still living in her own house with a maid. She still baked cakes and cookies, was still really active, and would send world’s best marble cakes to my home every month. A fall however caused her hips to be dislocated, but after the necessary surgery she refused to allow the physiotherapist into her house for…some reasons, and accused her live-in nurse who was giving light therapy to her muscles of poisoning her, so she stopped getting any therapies. She was therefore unable to walk, and her muscles have atrophied. She despised wheelchair since it reminds her of my late grandfather and “dead people”. She refused to move out of her house. So she essentially made herself bedridden. My mom finally moved her to our house and told her lies somehow so she doesn’t realize that she’s in a different house. She has a bad eyesight since long ago, and in the last few years she has started hallucinating and talking of weird things, mixing her imagination with the past and the present. Recently she has imaginary conversations with her ex-fiancee from 80 years ago (she never married), and last week she made a ruckus by angrily accusing my mom of preventing her to arrive at her wedding with her fiancee. It’s sad, really. She also often talks with her contemporaries, most of whom has passed away. When she’s completely lucid she actually still has amazing memories of so many things, but those moments are now few and far between. It must be very lonely, and even more so in her case because she’s confined in one room, with only her thoughts and regrets. This sounds selfish, but it’s not something I personally want to experience.

We moved to Ireland from the UK twenty-five years ago, and we brought my mother with us when she was ninety-one years old. We gave her a room in our new house and we looked after her as best we could, but the trouble was that I was involved in engineering projects outside of Ireland and was often away for weeks, and my wife found it increasingly difficult to cope with my mother’s needs since she was basically bedridden. Mum was lucid and in command of all of her mental faculties, but she was slightly incontinent and she needed a lot of help. Eventually the time came for a nursing home for her, where she could have 24/7 care. There she shared a room with another elderly patient, which was not something I liked, but I was having to pay the nursing home €13,000 a year for her care and I couldn’t afford a single room for her. She seemed to settle in very well there, and even got involved it the homes catering by trundling about on her Zimmer frame to set the tables for dinner. She told me that she liked it there, because there were people of her age that she could talk to over meals. One day, when I visited her, she said that her room mate had passed away in the night. “I hate that when it happens!” she said quietly. How could I respond to that? How could I sympathise with her when she was woken by the carers in the morning who were as quietly as they could removing a dead body from her room? My mother passed her one-hundredth birthday in her nursing home and, being an English citizen, she received her card from the Queen and a cheque from the Irish president. All the local newspapers published photos of Mum in her chair surrounded by care staff and family A few months later my mother developed a severe kidney infection and was hosptalised. In the hospital the doctors took me to one side and said that due to her age her condition was incurable without invasive surgery, and at her age they didn’t think she would survive that. They needed me to sign a form that simply said “No invasive surgery.” I was resigned and I agreed. I sat with her for hours, but she couldn’t talk to me. She just made whimpering noises and gripped my hand until she finally fell asleep. To my eternal discredit I decided to go home for an hour of two of sleep but then, in the earlier hours, a call from the hospital — “She is slipping away.” My wife, my son, and my wife got there just too late, and I never got to hold this woman who had given me so much, as she passed on to wherever we all go finally. I will for the rest of my life wrestle with my conscious that I didn’t stay with her for those last minutes. That, I suppose, is what it is like to be one hundred years old and still living. You are a burden, financial and family. You can’t walk and need nursing care all of the time, and you can’t even go to the loo without assistance. You hope for a visit from a son or daughter on the odd weekend for a chat that lasts for an hour before son/daughter needs to go when it becomes apparent that they have become bored and don’t know what to talk about anymore. All I know is that the morning after she passed away, compulsively, I got in my car and drove down to the banks of the river in a secluded spot and, although I had always prided myself as being a strong man, I cried my bloody eyes out for that woman and how I had left her when she needed me most.

Can’t tell you personally as I’ve some way to go but yesterday I had tea with a family friend who will be 101 in September. She is sprightly, upright, walks in the house without a stick and chatters away - is a little hard of hearing but otherwise bright as a button. She takes no pills of any kind and enjoys life to the full, especially doing jigsaw puzzles. She reads, cooks - but can’t lift heavy pans - and looks after the flowerbeds in the garden. One of her sons (74) lives upstairs in the house but, as he’s still working, he’s out a lot during the day, so Jean is on her own much of the time - but that’s fine with her, she catches up on phone calls to friends! Until she was 92, she gave remedial reading lessons to pupils at a school nearby (the one she went to as a child!); her husband died five years ago, when he was 97 - also bright but needed help getting dressed so a carer used to come in. So, what is it like to live to be 100 years old? Can’t answer for anyone else but, for Jean, it’s just another year. She was pleased to reach the milestone and get a card signed by the Queen but she doesn’t really think about her age, just seeing friends and enjoying everything she does. She isn’t the oldest at the monthly tea party she started five years ago - that honor goes to a woman who is 106! And she is just the same - keeps on going, smiles a lot and is happy!

Lonely. My great grandma Rosa lived to be 104 years old. When she turned 100 she was still living alone and only needed daily visits from her children and grandchildren. Her mind and body were still sound. She took walks around what used to be her apple orchard and still was fairly independent. My grandmother was one of her daughters that would visit often, she did this in shifts with her sister. One day, while visiting with her, my grandmother told me that she said this (roughly paraphrasing): “I am all alone. My husband is dead, my friends are dead, I have seen my children die. I have outlived everyone, I have no one left. I’m all alone.” To a certain extent this was true. She no longer had her husband or friends to confide in. She had given her children life, raised them, watched them grow up and start their families, and seen most of them die at respectable ages. The world that she knew was long gone and all she had was her house and property. A couple years later, her mind and body withered and a live in nurse was hired. When she passed away, our entire of family felt relieved that she did not die painfully. She lived a good life, died a peaceful death, and had many more good years than any one could ever imagine or ever hope to ask for. Rest in peace, Great Grandma Rosa.

Technology has changed a lot in 1000 years. Did you follow it or have you become lost in the fog? Even 80 year olds have trouble using a simple flip phone. Everyone around you are children now. Do you trust having your food prepared by a two year old? Well now it feels like that every day. The landscape has changed so much. Nowhere is home and everywhere is home. Same with people. You might forget names because you've heard so many by now and seen so many faces, they tend to blur together a bit. You might also have a lot of power though. Concider the skills you can gain in a 1000 years. 100 years seems like a lot, but it's not really. You always have to pick and choose what you have time and energy and interest to learn. With 1000 years, you could learn everything. On the other hand though, you could also be very bored. You know the ending of every story now. Even before it happens, you know how it'll go. You take a bite of food and it's the same as what you've had so many times before. Nothing seems original anymore. You push through it anyways though, because something always drives you to use your time for more. Doing more feeling more learning more, everything. Still, it's starting to get old. 1000 years is a pretty good run. Maybe it's time to concider your end. You might be starting to fall apart anyways. If it could be a peaceful end, maybe you'd rather have control over your death, maybe you've had a chance to learn how. It's ok though, because your children are there. Nothing is perfect, but it never was. It doesn't matter anymore. Maybe it's their turn.

My wife’s grandmother is 105 and still kicking, er, shuffling around. She’s going downhill fast, but she still lives at home with her daughter who is in her eighties. She survives by routine and having a very simple life. She has outlived one of her sons. At one hundred she was still quite alert and seemed to enjoy the attention, but the fact is, even at that point she was relatively infirm. She tires very easily. Her body is worn out, she’s been losing her teeth and her heart could go at any moment. It just wasn’t made to go on this long. She was never a person of great wisdom, rather, she has always been quite set in her ways. (I’ve known her for 30 years.) I don’t imagine that she feels very good, but she doesn’t complain, much. Her brain doesn’t function very quickly and she forgets a lot, although she still remembers my wife every time we visit. I think she remembers me too, but it’s hard to tell. I expect that she will die this year. For her daughter’s sake I hope she does. She’s been more of a burden than a joy for several years now and has chained her daughter to a life of care giving. Her daughter’s health has been failing from the years of stress associated with this. It’s quite sad.

I saw this gentleman from near distance but did not meet him personally. He was 105 years old. He died a month ago and I attended his Funeral Prayers. Attendees were almost four fold than a normal funeral. After his departure from this world, I met his family and neighbors to know about his life which is here for you, too; He lead a life full of joy, enthusiasm & struggle. Faced hardships and went through every aspect which could be imagined in such a long span of time. He was born in India and migrated to Pakistan while he was 40. Saw the Independent Movement and then division of sub continent into two new countries, India & Pakistan. Passed thru the process of migration alongwith his family under a continuous fear looming on their head for death. Reached Pakistan with nothing in hand and started his life from scratch in 1947. He had SEVEN Children and saw his 4th generation (Excluding his generation) flourishing in front of his eyes. His wife died almost 40 years ago when he was 65 and lead his life as a single parent but alongwith rest of his family who never let him feel alone or lonely. His direct family members count to 70+ at this moment. He always felt himself young and strong from his heart. He was not dependent on anyone until a month before his death when his leg bone broke in an accident. He was energetic, motivated and a source of motivation for all community around him. His secret of leading a good and balanced life was in good deeds, philanthropic activities, participation in every common cause, simple food, walk, playing not only with his own family children but every child around the streets offering them toffees (which he used to keep in his pocket all the time), performing all religious rituals regularly. He used to spend his pension on arranging gifts for his grandsons / daughters for their weddings, birthdays and marriage anniversaries. All these traits and practices have made him very popular among all community members and family. It is quite natural that very old age returns the man back to its childhood and he often behaves childish. This is a norm and people around him are well aware of this change. This was also seen in him occasionally. Meeting such a person is like consulting an Encyclopedia or reading a book / autobiography consisting of several volumes full of wisdom and practical experience or watching an informative movie covering multiple topics of great interest.

This is second hand from my grandmother (so third hand from here) so here goes… First off, my grandmother is 84 years old. She is in good health, but my family has a dark sense of humor, so she makes a few ‘old lady’ and ‘I could be dead any minute’ now jokes. It’s not as bad as it sounds. Anyway…she lives in an apartment complex that is mainly senior citizens (not an assisted living or nursing home; same apartment complex as Sandra Day O’Conner). She has a few friends over 100 years old. They tend to be vital, she says. They all have something to do; whether visiting family or some hobby or some part time job. I’m not superstitious in any way, and neither is my grandmother, but at 100 years or older you’re not going to keep living unless you have something to do. People tend to waste away into their 80s; people who make it to 100 tend to just die without going through much of the worse shittiness that old age can bring. They’re not 20 year old athletes of course, but they tend to be active in some way.

I cannot answer directly, but I know my Grandpa pretty well, and he is 104 years old.  You are dependent on others for just about everything. It is annoying, but you are accustomed to it now.All of your real friends, and many of your loved ones, are dead. So life is rather lonely.People expect you to have brilliant reasons for your longevity, but honestly, you do not have "the key" to long life. It just worked out this way.You don't see or hear well, which makes it tough to read or watch television. Getting postal mail is wonderful. It helps you feel connected to family. Sending mail is troublesome, though. You prefer the telephone.It is nice to gaze at photos of people you love, but do not see often.You sleep a lot.Food is less appealing than it used to be.The world, and life on earth, seems more amazing than ever. And also more screwed up than ever.We had a huge party when Grampa turned 100. I hope he lives to be 105, when we can really cut loose!

Happy My 104 year old grandma plays up her “rock star” status achieved by being so old (and not looking or acting it). She has that Southern charm and works it on everyone. She just won a big basket of puzzles as a result of winning at dominoes. She does puzzles everyday and enjoys reading. She likes to talk about politics and personal relationships. She likes to put on a pretty dress and walk up and down the halls to go greet people. She thinks she is “being a stinker” when she does this because she thinks people expect her to be so old that she should be sitting around drooling. So she likes to surprise them. She wants to go to Mrytle Beach to visit her extended family, but feels my Aunt is not comfortable with the travels. Believe it or not, men still want her. She does not want them though. She says she just will not take care of anyone any more, also she thinks they don’t dress well and keep good personal hygiene. She is sad about everyone who has died in her life. And that will never go away. But she is pretty stubborn and looking forward to living as long as she can. She is amazed that she has lived so long and looks forward to see how long she can take it. Every year she plants new seeds in between the flowers in the landscaping and likes to watch they sprout and grow. She was raised on a farm and raised her kids from her own vegetables and chickens.

I can’t answer for myself as I have a way to go yet. However, my mother is 91. She is still alert and lives alone by choice. (She probably shouldn’t be, but…..) She has see lifelong friends die, she has see her husband die, she has seen all her siblings and their spouses die, she has seen all her husbands sibling and spouses die, she has seen a son-in-law and two grandchildren die. She has even see two of her own children die. She no longer hears well even with hearing aids. She is very unsteady on her feat. She is tired and lonely. There are still many friends around and her remaining child (me) spends a lot of time with her. (As a widow, myself, I don’t live with her by her choice). It isn’t a lack of caring people aroun her, people she also cares for, it is the loved ones she has watched die that she is lonely for. Life no longer holds much for her, and she is just biding her time … waiting.

I had a friend who recently died at 101 years of age. I asked him this very question, and he said that his only complaint was that the “restless leg syndrome” was a real bother. Incidentally, in my opinion a big reason he lived to that age is that he and his new girlfriend(they were both widowed) decided to renovate a farm house in Maine while in their 70s! That seemed to keep them both mentally and physically active for over 20 years. Then when he was 101 his girlfriend broke up with him because instead of her caring for someone else, she wanted to be cared for by her own daughter. Then his health rapidly deteriorated and he died just a couple of months later. He had offered to pay both their expenses in a retirement home and would surely have made sure she was taken care of until death. Instead, she is now practically penilesss (her “saving for retirement” was to buy antiques, which now have little value) and making life difficult for her daughter.

Miserable. At least in my eyes. I was lucky to have my great-grandfather Joe Eaton (or affectionately known as Papa Joe) for 102 years. He died when I was 20. During my life in Oklahoma and my subsequent visits to my great-grandparents I learned of many things, including the the great depression and the dirty thirties. While you live for that long you see many things. Grandpa and Grandma were hoarders to an extent. Looking through their piles of magazines they had Time magazines that included the space age. Even for ranchers in rural Oklahoma, they have seen far more change than what my generation may ever see. However, you also experience far more pain than most. Living for 102 years you see plenty of death. Nothing shook him worse than losing his wife of almost 80 years. Once she died, he became lonely and almost careless of his life. He remarked to me before he passed that "I want to be with my love". Living for that long has its great moments and terrible hardships. Seeing Papa Joe like that makes me feel I would not want to be that old.

I imagine at that age you have seen a lot. Theres a lot ro be thankful for, and theres sadness to follow. You watch your family grow and youre attached to them with every day to come. You build that bond more and more, but as you age you realize that one day it will end. You have to leave the ones you love, and you cant help but feel their sadness about it. Living very long is rare now and Im sure it is a treat. You see many generations come and go, new laws and regulations, buildings and roads. Everything has advanced since your time. You are one of the most ancient artifacts walking the earth when you reach 100, and Im sure it is an honor. You hold the oldest knowledge, and some of the new. You get to turn around and see the progress of the world. I imagine at that age, you feel accomplished. Especially if youre still moving around quite well to experience more. Can you imagine the change that person has seen? Both good and bad. There were once people whom lived to 300… since I live in the now, that would be torture LOL

My Great-great Aunt Ethel was born in 1912, the year the Titanic sank. She was six years old when WW1 ended, and worked as a telephone operator in WW2. She has lived through the Roaring Twenties, the Great Depression, the Swinging Sixties, up until now. She is 104 years old, and is like a living, shuffling textbook. She used to send me birthday cards, but I think she forgot me when she turned 98. When she turned 100, she got a letter from President Obama and a photograph. I'm pretty sure she thinks she's still in the Great Depression.

My great grandmother is nearly that age, 97, so I'll answer for her. She just moved into a nursing home last year, and everyone is younger than her there. She can't find anyone that can relate to her or what was going on during her life (her childhood was during The Roaring Twenties and The Great Depression.) Overall, it seems pretty lonely.

My aunt lived to be 100. I talked to her shortly before her hundredth birthday. Her complaint was that in her mind she was 16 and wanted to get up and dance, but she had nothing but pain when she moved. Her vision was blurry, her hearing was almost gone, and her teeth were failing. She felt trapped inside her collapsing body, which betrayed the ambitions of her mind. Eubie Blake (allegedly) summed it up when he said, “If I'd known I was going to live this long, I would have taken better care of myself.”

Ur existence is measured in terms of years u lived.Few again categorise as meaningful n dissatisfied years.Taking every ambiguity into account,it is just a number which really never matters except pen n paper.We lived so far never do we imagine for the years we lived!We just live the way around us.Our family,friends,relationships n all just takes new forms with either addition or deletion of old ones.We never compare we lived hurrah!25yrs or so.We will if at all live for 100 yrs simply preparing our grave in grace of mind. 100 may be much for others but for an individual who lives such can explain naturally it's relevance with utmost humility.

My 98 year old Godfather just passed away last month. Complications from pneumonia. It takes strength of body, mind, and character to live that long. That is something most of us don't have. “Old age ain't for sissies”, he would say. It's true. Living into old age means constantly learning how to adapt to one's failing body. How many people do you know who say things like, “I used to ski, or bike, or jog or swim,, or… but I can't anymore”. They never learned to adapt to their changing bodies and those are the people who will not live to a ripe old age. No one is going to have the body of a 25 year old forever! My mother is 86 now and can no longer read. Failing mind. She has chosen not to keep her mind engaged, instead she relied on my late Godfather to read her mail to her. Now what is she to do? Now she has to rely on others to care for her for the rest of her existence. That is not life, that is not living. How we choose to live our lives every single day is the key to a long life. What are you doing to live a long, engaged life? How have you adapted to change with age?

Ahem. You will wish to be crushed by a mountain if you manage to live this long. As health problems arise, none of your previous generation gp doctors would be around to assist. Eventually even the newspaper guys will grow tired of you. Your millennial currency will be completely redundant. Part of you might have been replaced by Android technology. By then you would have to be saturated with moisturizers, due to the brittleness of your skin. You'd be on constant Calcium supplement IV support, as your bone structure would have fused and fossilized. Though perhaps you may also become a Great Storyteller! 100years…I would say that's a fruitful period.

I always thought that would be cool to make it to a 100, not many do. Those are people that can tell you what it was like before there were cars, what it was like before there was TV, what it was like to live during the cold war, and what it was like long before man went to the moon. Someday we will be those people …. talking about what it was like before there was the internet, and what it was like before there were mobile devices. Hopefully we will also be talking about what it was like “back when isis and other terrorist attacks existed”.

Let’s try to understand the reason for living that long. If you are from developed countries and haven’t had any bad habits then you might want to consider for living that long. However you might have to retire around 70’s and you are not sure if you have enough money saved for your retirement which is for 30 years. Bright side, you could play with grand kids have tours and special privileges while travelling and people giving you way to get all the things completed sooner than middle-aged person. If you are from developed countries and had a spoiled childhood then you are not sure what kind of health issues you run into if you are living for that long. As per current situation I think 70 would be enough to do whatever you might want to achieve. If you are from underdeveloped countries, god forbid you might want 60 to be the end as you don’t have much to do by that time. I wanted to write more scenarios but I didn’t want someone to judge me so here are my two bits.

Last month I met a friend who lives with and partially takes care of a man who is 97 years old. The gentleman was a retired engineer who worked for MIT for most of his career and is a Japanese American. He is still driving a car, walks just fine without any help, climbs stairs, and apparently still has is private pilot’s license. So, he’s lucky with a good genetic background and I guess healthy living in many ways. More power to him!

My grandmother lived to be almost 105. She was born in 1898, and left 2003- so she witnessed three centuries. She can’t answer this question herself, but I think she felt like herself all of her life, except for the very last summer, and today I was thinking that- It took her over 100 years for her to say to me “I love you” and for me to answer back “I love you too.” So even after 100 years there are new good things.

I expect experience will vary, but by coincidence, today there was the news of a 104 year old Australian scientist who travelled to Switzerland to bring his own life to an end on his own terms. He was not terminally ill, but decided that his quality of life was such that he did not want to continue with it and flew to Switzerland to fulfill that wish. He gave a press conference on Wednesday. David Goodall, 104, Scientist Who Fought to Die on His Terms, Ends His Life

I have no idea . . . Not yet even 10% of the journey to that destination. BTW, who conjures up such inane questions? Must be on some sort of “strange stuff” ! ? To date I have had too many questions come my way which reflect an element of either stupidity or laziness, and apparent unwillingness to do a little on-line searching. just as I have to. I therefore no longer wish to be a participant in Quora. So, . . .for the second time,. . . I request no further contact.
You are much older than that, you just don't remember. That's like A day to you. We were known even before the creation. You should read more about this.
What's it like to be a hundred years old? I don’t know yet but I’ll update this answer in due time.
Ask me in 36 years… ;)
It depends on your body fitness。But i think when i am 100 years old i will feel the same as i am 3 years old。
I’ll let you know as soon as I teach trees to talk.
